title: Radiation from the Stars
description: This project uses Taylor Series to compare the Rayleigh-Jeans and Planck Laws, each of which attempts to measure the energy density of blackbody radiation as a function of its wavelength. These laws make similar predictions for long wavelengths, but not short ones.

title: Calculus and Baseball
description: This project explores three different applications of calculus to baseball concepts. They are (1) the impulse of a bat hitting a ball, (2) the work done to throw a pitch, and (3) the time it takes for a team to get a ball from the outfield to home plate.

title: Patterns in Integrals
topic: u-Substitution, Integration by Parts, Partial Fraction Decomposition
description: This project has students analyze four patterns in various integrals. After using a computer algebra system (integral solver) to solve a set of similar-looking integrals, students are asked to guess and then prove the general pattern. Note that the fourth question is solved using mathematical induction (and should thus be heavily scaffolded or removed).

title: The Gini Index
description: This project works with the Gini Index, which is a measure of income inequality, based on given data. Students will answer some theoretical questions on the Gini Index, then use a computer-given quadratic model and power model on given data to compute the Gini index.

title: Rotating on a Slant
description: This project asks students to derive a formula to compute the volume of the solid of revolution about a line y=mx+b (instead of the standard x-axis or y-axis). To scaffold this, they are first asked to derive a formula for the area between a curve and the slanted axis.

title: How Fast Does a Tank Drain?
description: This project has students work with Torricelli's Law to model liquid draining from a tank. Students will solve separable differential equations to calculate the amount of time it takes to drain different-shaped tanks and conduct an experiment on a 2-liter plastic soft drink bottle to compare to the theoretical results.

title: Which is Faster, Going Up or Coming Down?
description: Suppose you throw a ball into the air. Do you think it takes longer to reach its maximum height or to fall back to Earth from its maximum height? Students will solve the problem in this project, with scaffolded steps, getting a graphical answer and an algebraic answer.

title: Logistic Sequences
description: Students will use a computer program of their choice to plot sequences based on the logistic difference equation p_{n+1}=kp_n(1-p_n) for various choices of p_0 and k. They will comment on the convergence (or lack thereof) of each sequence, and explore which conditions affect the convergence.

title: An Elusive Limit
description: This project deals with a function with a difficult-to-compute limit. Students will use numerical approximation, graphs, L'Hospital's Rule, and Taylor Series to attempt to compute this limit, with the help of a Computer Algebra System as needed.

title: How Newton Discovered the Binomial Series
description: This project asks students to write a report on Isaac Newton's discovery of the binomial series, comparing the equations and notation Newton used to our notation.

title: Running Circles Around Circles
description: In this project, students will work with parametric equations for hypocycloids and epicycloids, which are shapes generated by the motion of a point on a circle that rolls inside or outside another circle. Students will graph these shapes for different-sized circles and investigate the results.

title: Bézier Curves
description: In this project, students will experiment with Bézier Curves, prove some of their theoretical properties, and construct some simple shapes with them.

title: Families of Polar Curves
description: In this project, students will plot families of polar curves and explore the shapes they can take for different constants.

title: Power Reduction Formulas and High Dimensional Balls
description: In this project, you will use Integration by Parts to solve some trigonometric integrals, then apply this formula to compute the volumes of unit balls in more than 3 dimensions.

title: Integrate Any Rational Function
description: Students will solve an integral which involves Polynomial Long Division, the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, Partial Fraction Decomposition, u-Substitution, and Trig Substitution, on their way to demonstrating that any "rational function" (polynomial divided by polynomial) has an elementary antiderivative.

title: Gabriel's Horn
description: Students will use surface area and volume formulas to show the properties of Gabriel's Horn, a strange shape with infinite surface area but only finite volume!

title: Why (1/2)! Equals √π: The Gamma Function
topic: Integration by substitution, integration by parts, improper integrals
description: In this project, students practice integration by parts and u-substitution by computing certain values of the gamma function Γ with an application to probability theory.

title: An Explicit Formula for The Fibonacci Numbers
topic: Taylor Series; Series; Representing Functions as Power Series; Partial Fraction Decomposition
description: In this project, we will introduce a specific technique to calculate the Maclaurin Series of a function, and we will use this technique to derive an explicit formula for the Fibonacci sequence.

title: "Integrating" Calculus & CAD
description: The purpose of this project is to encourage students to make connections between abstract mathematical concepts and real-world applications. This project is not intended to serve as a deep-dive into mathematically challenging exercises. Rather, it is designed to offer insights into and an exploration of the utility of (even relatively simple) mathematics in engineering applications. The project illustrates a connection between integration techniques and 3-D computer modeling. It is designed to be accessible to new learners and supplement early- to mid- semester Calculus 2 instructional materials.

title: Fourier Series of Square and Triangle Waves
topic: Integration by substitution, series, applications to physics and engineering
description: In this project, students practice integration techniques by computing the Fourier series of square and triangle waves. As an application, they derive a beautiful formula for π.

title: Matter and Radiation in an Expanding Universe
topic: Differential equations, Applications of Taylor series

title: Neuron Firing Models
topic: Applications of differential equations, improper integrals, trigonometric substitution
description: For many biological processes, it is important to be able to understand when neurons are firing. Knowing the firing rate of a neuron and how it reacts to different stimuli can be useful for analyzing mechanisms such as muscle contraction and decision making. Neuron firing models can also help us understand the conditions that lead to seizures and consequently can be useful in developing treatments.
